spanishExample: ¿Viniste con alguna amiga?
englishTranslation: Did you come with some friend(f)?

spanishExample: ¿Viste que no tengo tantas cosas?
englishTranslation: Did you see that I don’t have so many things?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
viste: saw, you saw (Ver, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: A ver si tenemos un poco de tiempo.
englishTranslation: Let’s see if we have a little bit of time.

spanishExample: Algún hombre dijo que venimos.
englishTranslation: Some man said that we’re coming.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Algunos hombres y algunas mujeres son así.
englishTranslation: Some men and some women are like that.
vocabIncluded: así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"

spanishExample: Cualquier *phone* es mejor que no tener ninguno.
englishTranslation: Any phone(m) is better than having none.

spanishExample: Demasiados amigos dijeron que iban a venir, pero ninguno lo hizo.
englishTranslation: A whole lot of friends said they were going to come, but none did it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
iban: "were going", "they were going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person plural)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Quiero que veas que no hay tal cosa.
englishTranslation: I want you to see that there isn’t such a thing.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
veas: see, you see (Ver, subjunctive, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Estoy viendo que tienes tantas cosas que son suficientes.
englishTranslation: I’m seeing that you have so many things that they are enough.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: He visto ciertas cosas que no quiero ver de vuelta.
englishTranslation: I have seen certain things that I don’t want to see again.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Los tendremos cuando vengamos de nuevo algún día.
englishTranslation: We’ll have them when we come again some day.
vocabIncluded: tendremos: "will have", "we will have" (Tener, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Ninguna persona tiene suficiente *money* para *buy* esto.
englishTranslation: No person has enough money to buy this.

spanishExample: No quiero que venga con demasiadas cosas.
englishTranslation: I don’t want her to come with too many things.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
venga: come, he/she/it come (Venir, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Quiere que veamos esto y por eso vine.
englishTranslation: She wants us to see this and that’s why I came.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
veamos: see, we see (Ver, subjunctive, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Quiere que yo vea cada casa.
englishTranslation: He wants me to see each house.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
vea: see, I see (Ver, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Quiero que vengas ciertos días de la semana.
englishTranslation: I want you to come certain days of the week.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Si vienes vas a ver que hay pocos, así que ¿tienes alguno?
englishTranslation: If you come you’re going to see that there are few, so do you have any?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Tengo algunos hermanos, pero pocos amigos.
englishTranslation: I have several brothers, but few friends.

spanishExample: Teníamos bastantes amigos, pero ningún amigo fue tan bueno.
englishTranslation: We had quite a few friends, but no friend was so good.
vocabIncluded: tan: "so" as an adverb right before an adjective or adverb

spanishExample: Ve que cada persona es *special.*
englishTranslation: He sees that each person is special.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ve: sees, he/she/it sees (Ver, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Vemos que hay bastantes personas aquí.
englishTranslation: We see that there are quite a few people here.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
vemos: see, we see (Ver, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Ven cualquier *show.*
englishTranslation: They are seeing any show.
vocabIncluded: ven: see, they see (Ver, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Vengo aquí por tal razón.
englishTranslation: I come here for such a reason.
vocabIncluded: por tal razón: "for such a reason" (idiom)
vengo: come, I come (Venir, present, 1st person) NEEDS WORK

spanishExample: Vinimos *by bus,* ¿has visto alguno?
englishTranslation: We came by bus(m), have you seen any?
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Vio lo mismo que yo veo.
englishTranslation: He saw the same thing I see.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
veo: see, I see (Ver, present, 1st person)
vio: saw, he/she/it saw (Ver, preterite, 3rd person)
